pullRequest.body:
Add related lemmas about valuations. Add notations for integer, maximal ideal and residue field for valued field. Relocate files concerning `Valued` under a new folder Topology/Algebra/Valued.

Co-authored-by: Bichang Lei <leibichang58@ruc.edu.cn>

---

This is my first PR. Thank you!

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

The `IsValExtension` part is split to #14342 

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: Welcome to mathlib; thanks for your contribution! I presume you meant to mark this as ready for review, hence I have added the `awaiting-review` label to indicate so. (This label and a few related ones are explained on [this page](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html).)

### Import summary

No significant changes to the import graph

### PR summary [d68f154378](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13533/commits/d68f1543780230a3d50c06bddef84a9f347465f8)

#### Import changes

No significant changes to the import graph

---

`+ val_lt_one_iff`

This looks good to me and I'll maintainer merge this viewing the lack of suggestions from other reviewers as a non-objection.
maintainer merge
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by erdOne.

@faenuccio I have a technical question about splitting the PR. Should I close this PR and open new ones? Do you know some easy ways for me to select some files and discard changes in other files in a PR? Thank you!

> @faenuccio I have a technical question about splitting the PR. Should I close this PR and open new ones? Do you know some easy ways for me to select some files and discard changes in other files in a PR? Thank you!

The best way is to keep all the lemmas you want in this PR (so, do not close it!), and simply remove the extra-file. Then open a new PR adding only that file, marking in the comment that it depends on this one. Have a look at #13683 for instance.
Thanks for all your work!!! 🎉
maintainer merge
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by faenuccio.

:v: jjdishere can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9775338803/job/26985513378)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9775338803/job/26985513045)
Please update master on this branch, by the way!
Looks good to me! Just minor comments.

Thanks!

bors d+
Looks good to me! Just minor comments.

I made some comments improving the code and asking for some doc. I would suggest that you split this PR, first with all your additions and then another one adding only the `ValExtension` file, possibly after getting an opinion from María Inés.
Please update master on this branch, by the way!

Thanks!

bors d+

```suggestion
extension of valuations. Let `A` be an `R` algebra, both `R` and `A` are equipped with valued
```

```suggestion
instances. Here, extension of valuation means that the pullback of valuation on `A` is equivalent
```
Is there a reason why this is necessary?

My consideration here is to make instances equipped on `Valuation.integer` adopted to `Valuation.valuationSubring` automatically. Otherwise, these instances have to be written twice. (Similar things will happen for `Valued.integer` and `Valued.valuationSubring`, e.g. there will be different instances `Algebra vR.v.integer vA.v.integer` and `Algebra vR.v.valuationSubring vA.v.valuationSubring`) I doubt there will be any instances that should only work on `Valuation.integer` but not `Valuation.valuationSubring`.
Do you really need `Algebra vR.v.valuationSubring vA.v.valuationSubring` though? The main thing I'm concerning is about the performance impact.
A few weeks ago we just changed the definition of `ringOfIntegers` from a `Subring` to a `Type*` because of performance reasons and I'm afraid this is going the opposite direction.

> Do you really need `Algebra vR.v.valuationSubring vA.v.valuationSubring` though? The main thing I'm concerning is about the performance impact.

Yes, I need it to create the `IsLocalRingHom vR.v.valuationSubring vA.v.valuationSubring` instance, when `R` and `A` are fields. So should I indeed write all these instances twice? That's acceptable.
I'm not sure I understand what `IsLocalRingHom vR.v.valuationSubring vA.v.valuationSubring` means
Sorry, it should be`IsLocalRingHom (algebraMap vR.v.valuationSubring vA.v.valuationSubring)`.
Why not `IsLocalRingHom (algebraMap vR.v.integer vA.v.integer)` then? And maybe put `LocalRing` instances on `vR.v.integer` instead.

Well, if we only use `vR.v.integer` instead of `vR.v.valuationSubring` in instances, mathematically you simply lose some information when `R` and `A` are fields. For example, in some propositions, one really needs that `vR.v.integer` is a valuation subring of `R` and ` IsScalarTower vR.v.integer vA.v.integer A` together. It would be inconvenient to do this without `IsScalarTower vR.v.valuationSubring vA.v.valuationSubring A`.
Hmmm. Do you have an example? Mathematically $A \hookrightarrow \mathrm{Frac}(A)$ with $A$ being a valuation ring should be everything `valuationSubring` entails.

> Hmmm. Do you have an example? Mathematically A↪Frac(A) with A being a valuation ring should be everything `valuationSubring` entails.

Yes, you are right. What I need is exactly $$A \hookrightarrow \text{Frac}(A).$$ But for general `R`, we do not have `R = Frac vR.v.integer` unless `R` is a field. So do you think I should write instances like`LocalRing vR.v.integer` and `IsFractionRing vR.v.integer R` when `R` is a field (they fail when `R` is not a field)? If I use `vR.v.valuationSubring`, they can be inferred automatically.

Yes I'd prefer `ValuationRing vR.v.integer` and `IsFractionRing vR.v.integer R` over putting more structure on `vR.valuationSubring` in case we would like to make `Valuation.integer` a type in the future due to performance concerns.
I see, I'll work on it. Thank you for your suggestion! I learned a lot : )
I think this (and many results below) does not actually need the topological structure and should use `Valuation` instead of `Valued` and go in `RingTheory/Valuation`.

I agree that these results do not actually need the topological structure. The idea of choice here is that, for convenience, I want to make this into a typeclass so that Lean can infer it automatically. (Since almost all field extensions that people care about in the local case are extensions of valuation, and there are lots of theorems that need this condition, especially when talking about a tower of extensions `L/M/K`, `IsValExtension M L` is frequently needed.) `Valued` is a class, but `Valuation` is not a class. What do you suggest here?

What about
```
class IsValExtension {R A ΓR ΓA : Type*} [CommRing R] [Ring A]
  [LinearOrderedCommGroupWithZero ΓR] [LinearOrderedCommGroupWithZero ΓA]
  [Algebra R A] (vR : Valuation R ΓR) (vA : Valuation A ΓA) : Prop where
  /-- The valuation on `R` is equivlent to the comap of the valuation on `A` -/
  val_isEquiv_comap : vR.IsEquiv <| vA.comap (algebraMap R A)
```
So that `IsValExtension vR vA` still can be inferred automatically.

I think most of these exists one way or another in `RingTheory/Valuation/Basic.lean` near `IsEquiv`. If there is anything missing it should be added there, and I don't think we have to restate them when one of the arguments is a restriction.
Thank you! I'll move or delete these lemmas.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion [LinearOrderedCommGroupWithZero ΓK] [LinearOrderedCommGroupWithZero ΓA] ```

If you state it like this, it can be an instance (and it is more general)
```lean
instance {K A ΓK ΓA : Type*} [CommRing K] [Ring A]
    [LinearOrderedCommGroupWithZero ΓK] [LinearOrderedCommGroupWithZero ΓA]
    [Algebra K A] (vK : Valuation K ΓK) (vA : Valuation A ΓA) [IsValExtension vK vA]
    [NoZeroSMulDivisors K A] :
    NoZeroSMulDivisors vK.integer vA.integer := by
  refine ⟨fun {x y} e ↦ ?_⟩
  have : (x : K) • (y : A) = 0 := by simpa [Subtype.ext_iff, Algebra.smul_def] using e
  simpa only [Subtype.ext_iff, smul_eq_zero] using this
```
(you can still provide `integerAlgebra_injective` below; and it should be called `algebraMap_injective`.)
Thank you. I'll add the instance and rename `integerAlgebra_injective` to `algebraMap_integer_injective`
Similarly I think `IsValExtension.algebraMap_injective` is a good enough name. It is short but distinctive enough, and it aligns with the rest of the library.

Is there a danger that this theorem name without containing `integer` would make people think of this theorem? (Maybe this theorem will not get into mathlib anyway ...) 
`theorem IsValExtension.algebraMap_injective {K A ΓK ΓA : Type*} [Field K] [Ring A]
    [LinearOrderedCommGroupWithZero ΓK] [LinearOrderedCommGroupWithZero ΓA]
    [Algebra K A] (vK : Valuation K ΓK) (vA : Valuation A ΓA) [IsValExtension vK vA] [Nontrivial ΓA] :
    Function.Injective (algebraMap K A) := sorry`

And this reminds me that I should add a theorem that states `Nontrivial ΓA` implies `Nontrivial A`

My reason is exactly because this lemma shouldn't be in mathlib. You should get the `Nontrivial A` instance and use `RingHom.injective`.

Also you should generalize `RingHom.domain_nontrivial` to `MonoidWithZero.domain_nontrivial` if you need the last result that you mention.

This works for arbitrary rings as long as the map `K -> L` is also a local ring hom.
```lean
instance instIsLocalRingHomValuationInteger {K L ΓK ΓL : Type*} [CommRing K] [CommRing L]
    [LinearOrderedCommGroupWithZero ΓK] [LinearOrderedCommGroupWithZero ΓL]
    [Algebra K L] [IsLocalRingHom (algebraMap K L)] {vK : Valuation K ΓK} {vL : Valuation L ΓL} [IsValExtension vK vL] :
    IsLocalRingHom (algebraMap vK.integer vL.integer) where
  map_nonunit r hr := by
    apply (Valuation.integer.integers (v := vK)).isUnit_of_one
    · exact (isUnit_map_iff (algebraMap K L) _).mp (hr.map (algebraMap _ L))
    · apply (Valuation.integer.integers (v := vL)).one_of_isUnit at hr
      exact (val_map_eq_one_iff vK vL _).mp hr
```
Note that we might be missing this instance somewhere
```lean
instance (priority := 100) {K L} [Field K] [CommRing L] [Nontrivial L]
    (f : K →+* L) : IsLocalRingHom f where
  map_nonunit r hr := by simpa using hr.ne_zero
```
Thank you. I will put this instance inside the file `Mathlib.RingTheory.Ideal.LocalRing`.

```suggestion
  smul r a := ⟨r • a,
    Algebra.smul_def r (a : A) ▸ mul_mem ((val_map_le_one_iff vR vA _).mpr r.2) a.2⟩
  __ := (algebraMap R A).restrict vR.integer vA.integer
    (by simp [Valuation.mem_integer_iff, val_map_le_one_iff vR vA])
  commutes' _ _ := Subtype.ext (Algebra.commutes _ _)
  smul_def' _ _ := Subtype.ext (Algebra.smul_def _ _)
```
Also please provide a simp lemma for smul.
Thank you! I will add `coe_smul_integer`

```suggestion
    rw [← Valuation.mem_integer_iff, ← Valuation.mem_integer_iff, ← h]
```
This should be `ValuationRing v.integer`, be provided below `ValuationRing.of_integers`, using that lemma.
I'll move it and modify the proof.

We should first show that for a valuation ring `A`, `K` is the fraction ring if the map is injective and either `x` or `x⁻¹` is in the range for all `x ≠ 0`, and then show this for `Valuation.Integers` and finally specialize to `v.nteger`.
I'll split it into 2 instances and a theorem. Thank you.

```suggestion
theorem val_algebraMap (r : vR.integer) :
```
I think the namespace `IsValExtension` is informative enough that we don't need to specify `integer`?
Also `coe` does not appear in the signature of the lemma (in the info view you can see that it is `Subtype.val`), so it should not appear in the name.
Thank you, I'll change this name.
Also change the new smul lemma's name to `IsValExtension.val_smul`

```suggestion
variable {R A ΓR ΓA : Type*} [CommRing R] [Ring A]
```
Can you add a brief docstring describing the difference between this and the unprimed version?
OK, I'll add some docstring for both this theorem and the unprimed version, explaining their relation and the theorem itself.

```suggestion
  constructor <;> intro h
  · constructor
    · intro x
      obtain (⟨a, e⟩ | ⟨a, e⟩) := (iff_isInteger_or_isInteger 𝒪 K).mp inferInstance x
      exacts [⟨a, .inl e.symm⟩, ⟨a, .inr e.symm⟩]
    · exact IsFractionRing.injective _ _
  · constructor
    · intro a
      simpa using h.2.ne_iff.mpr (nonZeroDivisors.ne_zero a.2)
    · intro x
      obtain ⟨a, ha⟩ := h.1 x
      by_cases h0 : a = 0
      · exact ⟨⟨0, 1⟩, by simpa [h0] using ha⟩
      · have : algebraMap 𝒪 K a ≠ 0 := by simpa using h.2.ne_iff.mpr h0
        rw [inv_eq_iff_eq_inv, ← one_div, eq_div_iff this] at ha
        cases ha with
        | inl ha => exact ⟨⟨a, 1⟩, by simpa⟩
        | inr ha => exact ⟨⟨1, ⟨a, mem_nonZeroDivisors_of_ne_zero h0⟩⟩, by simpa using ha⟩
    · intro a b hab
      simpa [h.2 hab] using ⟨1, one_mem _⟩
```
We should have `Valuation.val_le_one_iff`

Yes! I'll do this.

Should we have four lemmas? `one_lt_val_iff`, `one_le_val_iff`, `val_le_one_iff`, `val_lt_one_iff`? Or only two of them?
Hmmm. Or maybe not and we should just `rw [map_inv₀, inv_le_one₀]`

I added four lemmas and the following one
```
-- This theorem is not stated in the strongest form but is very useful.
theorem val_le_one_or_val_inv_le_one (v : Valuation K Γ₀) (x : K) : v x ≤ 1 ∨ v x⁻¹ ≤ 1 := by
```
and used it to golf the `Valuation.valuationSubring`
Can you use this to golf `Valuation.valuationSubring`?
Sorry, what do you mean by "golf"?
Shorten the proof of. As in [code golf](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Code_golf).
Please consider moving this to L35. Then you don't need to repeat these assumptions on L40 and L100, etc.
Thank you! Fixed. There is a tiny difference between `LinearOrderedCommMonoidWithZero` and `LinearOrderedCommGroupWithZero` which makes things not completely trivial.
Please consider extracting these variables into a `variable` statement.
Thank you! Fixed.

```suggestion
  apply isUnit_of_one hv _ hvx
  apply IsUnit.mk0
  simp only [← v.ne_zero_iff, hvx, ne_eq, one_ne_zero, not_false_eq_true]

```

```suggestion
/-- Every ring hom `f : K →+* R` from a field `K` to a nontrivial ring `R` is a local ring hom. -/
```

```suggestion
  simpa [inv_inv] using (one_le_val_iff v (inv_ne_zero h)).symm
```

```suggestion
  simpa only [inv_inv] using (one_lt_val_iff v (inv_ne_zero h)).symm
```

```suggestion
  · simp only [← one_le_val_iff v h, le_total]
```
Why is this useful?

This lemma and the following lemmas are used in the proof of 
```
theorem IsValExtension.val_map_le_iff (x y : R) : vA (algebraMap R A x) ≤ vA (algebraMap R A y) ↔ vR x ≤ vR y :=
  (IsEquiv.val_le val_isEquiv_comap).symm
```
and `IsValExtension.val_map_lt_iff`, `IsValExtension.val_map_le_one_iff` ... These are simp lemmas for the class `IsValExtension`.

The restating of the definition is to make the name more consistent. When there are `val_lt` and `val_le_one`, it is better to also have a `val_le`.

What do you think about these lemmas?
What I mean is that it seems to me that they do not add anything, their proof is just one line and they cannot be simp lemma...
Then I will delete these lemmas and prove `IsValExtension.val_map_lt_iff` directly.
Can you explain why these three results are useful?
Same as above.
And what would be its strongest form? Why not stating it in that generality?

The strongest form is  `v x ≤ 1 ∨ v x⁻¹ < 1`. But based on my experience, many proofs just need you to discuss whether `x` or `x⁻¹` is an integer and the proof goes exactly the same afterwards (thus saves lots of lines if we use this form `v x ≤ 1 ∨ v x⁻¹ ≤ 1`). `v x ≤ 1 ∨ v x⁻¹ < 1` will make the `x⁻¹` case be treated differently with a small `le_of_lt`.
Perhaps add both lemmas, then, with the same name (and one with a `'` )
Is this related to valuations? Why is it here?

This is a special lemma for the design of `Valuation.Integers`. The math content here holds for all valuation subrings. However, for valuation subrings, since they are really subrings, there is no need to state something like `eq_algebraMap`. But for `Valuation.Integers`, it is a completely different ring `O` with an injective map into `F`, so we need this lemma.

```suggestion
  refine ⟨fun h ↦ ⟨fun x ↦ ?_, IsFractionRing.injective _ _⟩, fun h ↦ ?_⟩
  · obtain (⟨a, e⟩ | ⟨a, e⟩) := isInteger_or_isInteger 𝒪 x
    exacts [⟨a, .inl e.symm⟩, ⟨a, .inr e.symm⟩]
  · constructor
    · intro a
      simpa using h.2.ne_iff.mpr (nonZeroDivisors.ne_zero a.2)
    · intro x
      obtain ⟨a, ha⟩ := h.1 x
      by_cases h0 : a = 0
      · exact ⟨⟨0, 1⟩, by simpa [h0] using ha⟩
      · have : algebraMap 𝒪 K a ≠ 0 := by simpa using h.2.ne_iff.mpr h0
        rw [inv_eq_iff_eq_inv, ← one_div, eq_div_iff this] at ha
        cases ha with
        | inl ha => exact ⟨⟨a, 1⟩, by simpa⟩
        | inr ha => exact ⟨⟨1, ⟨a, mem_nonZeroDivisors_of_ne_zero h0⟩⟩, by simpa using ha⟩
    · intro _ _ hab
      exact ⟨1, by simp only [OneMemClass.coe_one, h.2 hab, one_mul]⟩
```
Can you explain the need for the choice of priority?

I think this is the case that the note [lower instance priority] will apply. This is an instance that will always apply during type-class resolution, so it should have a lower instance. I'll add the comments "-- see Note [lower instance priority]".

```suggestion
theorem isUnit_of_one' {x : O} (hvx : v (algebraMap O F x) = 1) : IsUnit x := by
  refine isUnit_of_one hv (IsUnit.mk0 _ ?_) hvx
  simp only [← v.ne_zero_iff, hvx, ne_eq, one_ne_zero, not_false_eq_true]
```
Can you add a reference to this result in the preamble of the file?

I added "We also show that, given a valuation `v` on a field `K`, the ring of valuation integers is a
valuation ring and `K` is the fraction field of this ring." at the preamble.
This works for `K` a division ring right?
You are right. Thank you!

```suggestion
/-- Every ring hom `f : K →+* R` from a division ring `K` to a nontrivial ring `R` is a local ring hom. -/
```

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat (RingTheory/Valuation): add class IsValExtension
